title: LAYING DOWN YOUR LIFE FOR THE SHEEP Part 2
scripture_text:
I am the good shepherd. The good shepherd lays down his life for
the sheep. The hired hand is not the shepherd and does not own the
sheep. So when he sees the wolf coming, he abandons the sheep and runs
away.Then the wolf attacks the flock and scatters it. The man runs away
because he is a hired hand and cares nothing for the sheep. "I am the
good shepherd; know my sheep and my sheep know me---just as the Father
knows me and I know the Father---and I lay down my life for the sheep.
have other sheep that are not of this sheep pen. I must bring them
also. They too will listen to my voice, and there shall be one flock and
one shepherd The reason my Father loves me is that I lay down my
life---only to take it up again. No one takes it from me, but I lay
it down of my own accord. I have authority to lay it down and authority
to take it up again. This command I received from my Father.
devotional:
I am the Good Shepherd

When Jesus says 'I am the Good shepherd and the Good Shepherd lays
down his life for His sheep,' what is He saying? It is very easy to put
a post-Calvary interpretation on what Jesus is saying here, and assume
that Jesus is speaking about his death on the cross, but in doing this
we are taking the verses out of context, and missing the point.

Although there may be an allusion to the death of Jesus, this is not
its main point.

In making this passage about the death of Jesus, we will
subconsciously detach or distance ourselves from it. This will cause us
to turn ministry into more of a convenience than a calling, because we
will never believe that God would expect us to 'lay down our lives for
the sheep;' yet this is precisely what God expects. Irrespective of the
ministry we may have been called to, it will require us to live a 'laid
down' life. Irrespective of the gifts we may or may not have, we will
need to live a laid down life, if we are gong to authentically reflect
Jesus and meet the needs of others.

The people who originally heard Jesus speak these words, would not
have associated them with His redeeming death on a cross.

A good shepherd will risk his life to protect the sheep, but that is
different from laying down one's life. The shepherd, who risks his life
for the sheep does not expect to die, but expects to live. Occasionally,
a shepherd will die in an encounter with animals or thieves, but most
will not. They plan, not to lay down their lives through death, but to
lay down their lives through a living a selfless life.

A wise shepherd would not plan on loosing his life, for he knows that
this would be of no benefit to his sheep; he may have an accident, or he
might be attacked by thieves and robbers, but to deliberately plan to
loose his life would be very serious for his flock. A shepherd who dies,
leaves the sheep defenceless, so the only good shepherd is one who is
alive.

Jesus did not lay down his life on the cross. The cross was only
possible because he had already laid down his life.

So what does it mean to 'Lay down your life?'

**The word Jesus uses four times in this passage for lay down is the
Greek word tithemi which means to set in place, to establish, to ordain.
In Acts 20 v28 Paul has summoned the elders from Ephesus together and to
them he says, \"Take heed therefore to yourselves and to the flock over
which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers.\" The word \"made\" is a
translation of the Greek word tithemi*.* 1 Tim 2:7: Paul was ordained a
preacher and an apostle. The word \"ordained\" is the Greek word
tithemi.**

So to 'lay down' your life is to have your life in the right place, to
find God's ordained purpose for it.
prayer:
Father, thank you that it has been ordained that we all lay
down our lives, help to see how this needs to look like in my life.
